- Interesting work
- People are great

cons:
- Health Benefits are below-average & costly
- Physical office locations are generally quite old & run down (office furniture is OLD)
- No overtime pay
- Furloughs can and do happen from time to time (typically driven by industry cycles)
- Working OT (w/o pay, mind you) is expected if you are on a "hot" program or you are a Lead/Manager

review_title: Interesting, high-tech design work.  VERY poorly managed company.
pros: Extremely high-tech products and design opportunities at Mpls location. Still a few extremely bright, late-career engineers left to potentially provide learning/mentoring opportunities. (though this has dwindled significantly during covid layoffs and cuts to higher salaried employees)...
cons:
Poorly managed company from the top down. Job role quickly outpaces career progression for early career engeers, as promotions are almost nonexistent. Salary increases, upon promotion are dismal, at best.
Quarterly earnings numbers are companies' #1 concern. Employees come last (despite the constant internal self-promoting 'propaganda'). This can be summed up by a comedic example: Prices for employee "discounts" or accommodations on general consumer products is always significantly more expensive than prices found in local retailers...
Months after annual salary increases within Aerospace were approved (following a stellar & record year in earnings + revenue where many engineers and other salaried employees put in significant unpaid overtime) - they were all were cut to 0% a couple weeks before they were to take effect... Rational was "covid", despite PPE business unit taking in money hand over fist, alongside $15B in free govt handouts (which doesn't require repayment - similar to those received by airlines during 2020). The kicker? Executives & upper management made sure to pay themselves out their tens of millions in annual insentive/performance bonuses, less than a week before rolling back everyone else's salary increases to a flat zero for the previous record-breaking year...
Though not immediately apparent, HON hires PR firms to combat negative reviews online. I'd advise prospective employees to peruse through the endless stream of posts over the last few years on TheLayoff dot com...
Loosing market lead & competitiveness for many Mpls products at an alarming rate...

pros: Work culture is good in Honeywell
cons: Honeywell gives very less salary

review_title: Honeywell Voice Solutions, Stay away at all costs!
pros: *The front line workers and managers who built the product and business before Honeywell acquired still working there. There are still a few left, but unfortunately Honeywell has shown that within the last year they will remove positions without fully preparing for who and how the work will be handled.
cons:
*Very little to zero career opportunities
*Exceeding yearly goals and having merit increases removed
*More than 1 furlough a year
*Senior management focused on customer only, with little to no concern for employee development
*Worst communication ever witnessed within a business, Voice solutions was a small group within Intelligrated and items such as RIFs, furloughs, merit increase removal would be passed down well after the fact leaving managers zero time to prep to deliver news to employees
*Dishonest business tactics
*People with over 10 + years experience given 1 days notice that Honeywell no longer needs them. 
*No support for next generation product development
*Moving of Voice office building into downtown area because poor business decision made by Honeywell Robotics group. Not taking into considerations the double of commute time for most of their employees. Parking wasn't even thought about until after the fact now employees have to walk two blocks to work in the winter months in Pittsburgh.

review_title: Top class multi industrial powerhouse with challenging work and great place to learn and develop
pros: Good commit to technology, IOT and furthering existing technologies in plants, buildings, aerospace and materials. Challenging work. Good work is rewarded and careers are accelerated. Goals are ambitious and broad. Real asset in sales and channels of distribution: multi channel powerhouse. Executives and key roles are strong in talent and great place to learn and develop. Leadership and "edgy" improvement principles engrained by Dave Cote are there and alive and vibrant.
cons: Challenge to balance long term and short term results = the pressure to perform short term sometimes overwhelms seed-planting emphasis and capacity.  The number of near term/ urgent improvement initiatives is vast and over powering. The commitment to operational excellence through Honeywell Operating System (HOS) has lost some focus as company has gone headlong into IOT, which is right direction. Needs a recommit to HOS to go along with new strategy. Sometimes matrix mgmt execution is more complex and gets in way of speedy execution. Balance of leadership has swung from empowerment with controls and deep dives to telling how it should be done.

job_title: Senior Inside Sales Supervisor in Houston, TX
pros: The only pro was the facility was nice.
cons: I have never experienced such blatant racism at a company in my life. From the beginning I was lied to about why the salary of my white subordinate male employee was greater than my own. Then I know this may sound cliche but I literally had to deal with a woman name Karen on a daily basis speaking to me in a degrading and disrespectful manner! I was lied to about the commission structure and how it would be based on G&O my first quarter there then all of a sudden they changed it to another metric to ensure I didn’t receive a payout (mind you I took a salary pay cut when I accepted this position because I was sold on the high commission structure) after only being employed for 5 months and in the middle of the current state of America with racism and the light now being shined on it I had the courage to look elsewhere. I am so happy I did because I am now at a company they truly cares about inclusion and diversity and am being compensated not based on the color of my skin or my gender but because it’s what I deserve professionally! Oh, I also went thru 3 different managers in the short time I was there, none of them took the time to fight for me or even get to know me, clearly because I am a black female. If you are black and female stay away from this company they do not respect or celebrate us there.

job_title: Chemical Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: I specifically worked at Honeywell UOP, based in Des Plaines, IL as part of their Career Development Program. Your coworkers are amazing, and there's knowledgable mentors available to help in many matters. The salary is great as well! The opportunities available to me at the company were definitely promising. It's just too bad the company was greatly affected by the pandemic.
cons: I specifically worked at Honeywell UOP, based in Des Plaines, IL as part of their Career Development Program. Management and business groups were constantly changing. I never felt secure in my place at the company. They were quite unforgiving in their layoffs, choosing new hires, employees of over 10+ years, and college hires that had yet to even start (they rescinded their job offers after multiple delays). Main headquarters in Des Plaines was outdated and felt like I traveled back in a time machine to the 80's or 90's. It all felt very corporate in the sense that your manager really didn't care about you, and as well, your manager had very little control over the corporate mandates.

pros:
Coworkers were amazing when i started but they’re all gone now.
Pay used to be average now it’s below competitors.
cons:
The coworkers were great when I first started, then came layoffs, short staffing, and overworked employees: those that survive the layoffs are left to take over the workload of their former coworkers, for LESS money than 2019 as they cancelled all raises, and they furloughed everyone TWICE in 2020. They also had temporary layoffs, and they called back favourites first instead of going by seniority. Everything is about cost cutting, all forms of employee engagement are gone (can’t even get a free hat, and don’t even mention the words “Christmas party”), we’re expected to do Honeywell mandatory trainings but not charge overtime for it if you’ve already worked your hours. 

The management used to be amazing back in the day, but they too were laid off in the past few years and their previous roles merged with others in sherwood park who are completely disconnected from our local office. You’re scene as a number, it’s revenue or nothing, no one cares to send a happy birthday, or congratulations on 5 years of service, or ask about how you’re doing as a person. They dont care about the mental health of their employees.

Benefits? Dont even get me started on benefits. Every year our portion of the benefits goes up, while Honeywells portion goes down; even though they send out all these emails about how much profits are coming in. Pensions are non existent unless you were around before they cut them out, so all the newcomers dont get any which i didn’t even think was possible, but again cost cutting for the worker so the board and shareholder get more profits in their pockets.

Cant even find any office staff to help; its all offshored. 
IT - offshore (There’s one guy left in IT and even his job is not secure.)
PAYROLL- offshore
BENEFITS-offshore
 There used to be a ton of people willing to help if you needed something; now those couple people left have a common response “not my job” when asking for anything.

pros: The people. In my over 20 years working for Honeywell, the one constant was working with good people.
cons:
Constant change in upper levels have led to a disconnect with their employees as well as a pretty steep drop in morale. There is very little communication between the upper management and lower levels.
They pay is competitive for new hires, but moving up within the company is limiting, with caps on how much of an increase can actually be made, even if the change in skill levels is drastic. Multiple people left just to come back at a higher rate of pay because of this limit. 
The inability to hire locally puts an added strain on managers and supervisors since it forces them to work 14 to 18 hour days to manage people in various time zones (My average day was 14 hours). Many managers have to take on the work of the employees they are trying to replace to meet deadlines, so this increases the stress. Very little Work-Life balance.
There are no bonuses for lower level management or general employees other than a Bravo, which are giving sparingly, and the compensation is low, even when the performance reviews are high, leading to a disgruntled workforce. 
Change to process without any consideration for the impact on work flow or adherence to standards needed to meet certain certifications causes extreme stress to the people who have to maintain those certifications, especially QA.
The strive for quality was overwhelmed by the need to meet numbers. What was once an industry of Safety and Quality because a battle of meeting numbers with no focus on making sure the product met the need and standards the customer came to expect with the Honeywell name.

review_title: Bullied, Humiliated, Unsupported - Scapegoat for senior management screw-ups and bad company  decisions
pros: I experienced no pros at all
cons: Everything, my entire short experience was horrific, I left after 3 months. 2 weeks into the job my line manager was sacked, I was then given another line who hadn't worked in my product area. The business made awful business decisions which had catastrophic consequences on customers (had they known the truth, so many cover ups and untruths) It got so bad an NDA was put in front of me... I never signed it. This particular honeywell company had been acquired many years ago but that small narrow minded culture was alive and well amongst staff, even HR. It was a truly awful experience and I am only sorry I did not go to the media about what was going on within the business.... Loyal customers of years treated appallingly and staff being blamed for decisions made higher up the chain. Stay away from this organisation. I was honest and frank and told how it was and what I was seeing and experiencing, it didnt go down well that I was holding people accountable for their lack or no decision making at all, no plans in place, no systems and processes. I was 'marked down' because of it and when I was honest and told them I was unsupported and essentially being bullied, instead of having a duty of care to me, i was told off about the language I used. I wrote my resignation letter from immediate effect, gathered my things and walked out of this vile toxic company

review_title: Few Incentives to Stay, Lots of Reasons to Leave
job_title: Test Engineer II in Mason, OH
pros:
- The initial pay for most positions seems to be good. The increases afterwards are severely lacking, though.

- The benefits seem adequate to me.

- The hardware provided to employees is stellar in most cases, unless you receive a re-imaged laptop from another employee instead of a normal upgrade laptop.

- "Unlimited" vacation and reasonable sick time allowances.
cons:
- No Work From Home Policy
 Absolutely archaic way of looking at the work from home situation. Took corporate FOREVER to finally allow work from home during the pandemic compared to other businesses of similar caliber and size. The official plan is to have employees come back to the office 3 days a week starting July 6th, 2021, and then full-time back in the office sometime in the fall, September/October time-frame. With no planned exemptions or flexibility involved. The WFH policy up until this point is essentially "you can't" unless you're legally required to be allowed to. They claim that working in the office is better for collaboration and teamwork and innovation, but as an employee both before and after being purchased by Honeywell, I can tell you there is almost NO collaboration or innovation going on, nor is it actually incentivized. They just like the buzzwords.

- No Upward Mobility
 You would think a company like this would be incredibly interested in keeping the younger generation around and attracting young, new talent and retaining them to replace the "old guard" when they move on or retire, but they don't remotely care and it's obnoxiously evident. They drag out promotions for nearly a year or more, if you even get one at all. They get incredibly stingy with the raises when they actually do give them. They don't seem interested in giving you a career path, just expect you to be happy you're where you are and to stay there.

- 401K Paid Out Once Per Year
 They only pay 401k match once a year in January, meaning you lose out on potential dividends. interest gains, and general gains over the course of the year that they could have been matching monthly. This also means if you leave at any point other than right after you receive your match, you miss out on potentially 11 months worth of 401k match funds.

- Furloughs and Cut Cost-of-Living Raises are the Norm
 It's very typical to be furloughed, even as an engineer, for anywhere from 1 week to 1 full month every year. That's a lot of time that you can't really plan for to go without a paycheck, and there's no telling when they decide the financials need to look better, so everyone should take one for the team. They also frequently find excuses to not offer the yearly cost-of-living wage increases; Usually it's that the financial performance hasn't been great, despite having just shown slides that seemed an awful lot like the company was doing pretty good.

- Inefficient, Silo'd Engineering & Lack of Training
 Almost all engineering teams work in silos all the time and team collaboration is just handled at the end when it has to be done, instead of integrating things throughout the course of development. There is also little to no training. If you ever do go through training, it's usually way to late to have ever been useful, but the training itself isn't usually actually helpful in the first place so it's really wouldn't matter.

- Heavy Focus on Short-Term Stockholder Gains
 Most of the town-halls and other company-wide meetings usually cover financials from a high-level perspective talking about how great we are usually doing, and quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year financial improvements. As well as how great this would be for the stockholders. This wouldn't be such an issue if it weren't for the people that make the business profitable (the sales teams and the engineering teams) weren't treated as a disposable meat grinder. There is no conversation had about employee retention or what could be helpful to keep employees, giving the impression to back up the evidence, that they couldn't care less whether you stay or go.

 - Lots of Broken Promises
 They frequently like to have "surveys" that a mysteriously large portion of the company report never receiving and use these surveys to justify the state of things, while making "promises" and "plans" on how to "improve" things that NEVER actually come to fruition in any way more than an abstract "we should be doing this" conversation in a town-hall.

- Hemorrhaging Employees
 Employee retention seems to be the last concern to upper-management. I've heard losses of engineering employees described as "un-regrettable losses". That speaks for itself.

job_title: Lead Enterprise Architect in Tempe, AZ
pros: The compensation aligned with what I was expecting and the benefits were decent given the relationships and reputation Honeywell has with outside parties.
cons:
There are not enough words in this box to fully articulate the cons with this organization. 

I was horribly misled about the job position, description, and responsibilities. I relocated to Tempe, AZ for the position. Three weeks into the job I went on a mandatory furlough. Not exactly comforting considering I relocated over 1,000 miles for the position, selling my home, and living in a new area. Feedback from peers and others in the organization articulated this was "the norm" for the organization. 

I was told the position was identifying and collaborating with other business units to provide recommendations with the goal to increase the cybersecurity maturity and hygiene of networks throughout the enterprise. I arrive at the position and am ready to dive right in. "Another team manages that" or "another team is responsible for that" became frequent statements when asking questions. You have a question on a firewall? Go talk to this team. You have a question on how the network is configured? Go talk to that team. Any attempts to build a relationship, collaborate, request access (even view only) to learn the lay of the land and how things are configured ended up in black holes. Neither of those teams are forthcoming with information even though it was your assigned responsibility. I don't know whether it was the fear of job security or just internal politics, but it was nearly impossible to get anything done. If you had an idea or a suggestion, you had to have a meeting about it. Not only did you have to have a meeting about it, but you had to have a meeting to talk about needing to have a meeting for it. 8 hours in a 10 hour workday was spent in non-productive meetings, but they were mandatory and you couldn't get out of them. 

The internal politics are the worst that I have ever seen. 

My direct manager was great. He was always willing and able to try to clear any roadblocks I had, but even he couldn't bulldoze through the existing political roadblocks or immaturity of some of the other team and their leads.

I should have heeded HR's warning about the politics during onboarding more instead of just shrugging it off that every company has political issues.

pros: There are a lot of smart, talented people you will work with. However, the running joke is "it's the place where smart people go to feel bad about themselves." If you are willing to relocate, you can move up in the company.
cons:
Too many to list, but here are the main cons:
-Work/life balance: This is one of the biggest concerns across the company. We are a global organization so it's common to have early morning (6:00 am) and evening meetings (after 7:00 pm) and also working weekends and during "vacations". There is no consideration for personal commitments outside of work. You don't ever really get to take a vacation because you are still expected to check emails, attend meetings, etc.
-Workloads: Due to significant layoffs across the company, most people are doing the job of 2 and 3 people. During the pandemic, there were times where the finance teams were pulling all nighters and working until midnight most days of the weeks. We had employees quitting after a couple months due to the workloads.
-Diversity: Within the past year, they jumped on the diversity bandwagon but is disingenuous. I've observed them promote women or persons of color and shortly thereafter fire them and replace with a white male.
-Compensation/Benefits: Benefits are subpar, 0% vesting on 401k until 3 years. In order to get health benefits you have to do a medical screening. Compensation is terrible. 2020 was a tough year for most companies but Honeywell was still meeting their financial commitments to the street yet not giving salary increases and little to no bonus. Also, to increase savings for the year, they would layoff employees a few weeks prior to bonus payouts and merit increases.
-Culture: It's a punishment-based culture. The CEO sent an email to his leaders that ended-up making it's way throughout the org, basically encouraging his leaders to rule with an iron-fist, and by creating an environment of fear and more "stick" and less "carrot" will make you a more successful leader. They live for the month and quarter which means they will push and drive at all cost to meet their numbers to the street. This is great from a shareholder perspective, but unbearable at times from an employee perspective.

Many times the layoffs were during years where revenue numbers were up, however they were not getting close to the stretch goal forecasts they had communicated to Wall Street. They company is driven by ensuring the stock price is up which means they often take extreme cost-cutting measures for the inorganic growth. Many times this comes at the expense of the employees and even the customers. The executive level, especially in Aerospace, is completely toxic, they continually belittle people in meetings and on conference calls.

review_title: Great to learn, Challenge to life
pros:
1) You will work with some amazing people in this company!

The senior HR leadership team is made up of an ambitious, challenging and intelligent group of people who have a strong business sense and know how to ask the right questions, streamline processes for efficiency and take responsibility to get a job done.

2) Salary is higher than average

Honeywell tends to pay above market rate due to the culture of high performance high reward that is promoted within

3) The culture

The culture within Honeywell is not for everyone, but if you are looking for a challenge, interested in continuous development and willing and able to go the extra mile to perform then it may be a good fit for you. There is a lot to learn here and it can definitely stretch your comfort zone, which can be a good or bad thing
cons:
1) Work Life Balance

As with anything there are always two sides to a coin. Whilst Honeywell is an amazing place to work, it can be challenging to get your work-life balance right if you are looking to perform well. Nobody will actively encourage you to create that balance, so it is up to you to set your boundaries - so do not expect any kind of empathy or molly-coddling from this company. You’re there to work and be productive - that’s it

2) Flexibility

They removed the work from home policy before the pandemic on a global scale, meaning that working from home was not allowed unless you had a special exemption in place. This may have changed, but previously made it challenging to work flexibly within the company policy structure

3) Progression Opportunities

Although Honeywell is a huge company, they are also working towards streamlining their sites. As such, if you do want to move around you may find it challenging to find positions outside specific “hubs”. They have also been actively working at flattening the organisation to 6 layers from the bottom to CEO level and reducing the number of executives and Band 4 positions that they have, thus reducing the number of progression opportunities available once you reach a certain level

job_title: Senior Global Commodity Manager in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great pay and mediocre benefits.
cons:
They bill themselves as a technology company but they're really make profit by buying other companies. This creates many disconnected systems and non-robust processes which sets up the average employee for failure. You can be successful at Honeywell, but you're going to have to put in double the hours for the same result that you would have gotten at a more reputable company.

They're also more interested in manipulating their stock price via supply chain tricks than they are with driving stock prices up by delivering sold products to their customers. It's only a matter of time before all the work they get will be legacy work and then they're circling the drain. Stock price is inflated.

Timely support will be minimal, if at all.

job_title: Design Engineer III in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
1.	Brand- Good (UOP has very good reputation, but after Honeywell overtaken UOP- Brand name has started degrading. But still it is good)
2.	Documentation- Good (Well documented knowledge) 
3.	Compensation- Moderate (with respective to the workload, feel compensation is too low)
4.	Office timing- Feasible (since company is target based company; so office timing is not so important)
5.	Travel- Moderate (Frequent US or UK travel required but limited duration one or two weeks)
cons:
1.	Work load- High (comparatively high work load at NAO, Hydrotreating groups) 
2.	Training- Poor (skill training, technology training- Nil, but Company provides one time intensive training to get hand off of the UOP design tools)
3.	Work environment- Poor (Exp. people and Management feel insure and created a poor working environment)
4.	Ethics- less (not Employee friendly, Poor HR policies, unusual firing at critical/ pandemic situations without proper reason, Salary deductions, etc)
5.	Job Security- less (US based company- hire and fire policy. Anything can happen at any time) 
6.	Growth- Slow (initially 5 years growth will be slow, since it is management judging time of your capabilities)
7.	Knowledge- less (Well documented knowledge, but it is hard to get time to go through it)
8.	Engineering Tools- Up to mark (Well designed UOP engineering tool- we get knowledge how to play with the tools but not the content)
9.	Technology exposure- Moderate (until Process coordinator (min. 5years) is zero, later exposure is good) 
10.	Politics- High (Ratio of Managers to working staff is more, regional feelings are high)

Final words- Honeywell UOP is good brand company with moderate compensation, less Job Security Company and required minimum 5 years in the UOP to gain/ start some exposure in the technologies.

cons:
- Low pay
- They do not match your 401K on a monthly basis - they will deposit it at the beginning of the next year, so if you leave the company before mid-December, you get no 401K match for the year. None!
- No career ladder
- Global corporation that works to please its shareholders first
- They are good at spending millions to acquire other companies, but barely give employees a cost of living pay increase.

Honeywell makes it clear that many internal career paths are possible and encourages employees to actively pursue them.
cons: Management can be uneven, and the unified culture that existed in the small organization (within Honeywell) I joined has slowly become fragmented. As the organization has grown, an unfortunate amount of office politics and other non-productive managerial requirements have also increased.

job_title: Project Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Honeywell UOP was a great place to work with an amazing culture however that has all changed by the upper management/ELT actions or lack of actions. Communication is a major issue within the organization. There use to be a culture of learning and building together to provide our customer with the best service and equipment. That mindset is gone, it all lip service now. We are not even given the tools to do our job (takes a director to approve a request to replace a broken headset) and lack of basic support structure (onboarding, IT, admins).
cons: This year has been difficult for all. We went from hiring multiple people to 3 RIF, 3 weeks of furloughs, no pay increases, and early retirement packages. There is no communication from upper management which creates uncertainty and anxiety within the project teams. Projects are forced to use purchase services to complete tasks which leads to quality issues and delays. Upper management/ELT seems completely unaware of how their actions or lack of actions are perceived by the lower ranks

review_title: This ship appears to be sinking.
pros:
The jobs aren't hard as long as you pay attention and stay on top of them.
The pay was very good.
There are and were a lot of good people working there.
cons:
Layoffs "due to the downturn in the oil industry."
The training could and should be way better.
The plant is old and needs a major overhaul that probably will not happen.
There have been five HR managers in the last three years.
They implemented a new pay scale based on evaluations that will probably stop any new employee from ever topping out.
They over produced and stockpiled their most lucrative product, and now they are shutting down lines.
Honeywell appears to be driven by globalization at the expense of jobs in the U.S.

review_title: Shaping the Future...on a tight budget
pros: Honeywell middle management is generally flexible, forward thinking, and generally wants to be there / make a difference in their workplace. Honeywell has generally supported grassroots employee resource groups, such as networks for Women in Tech, LGBT, Veterans, Black, Latinx, etc. Growth areas of the company are generally rewarding to be a part of, and there are frequent opportunities for people to work on interesting technology.
cons: Honeywell, at the high levels, employs a hardball culture, and expects to win every short-term negotiation it participates in, whether it is with customers, suppliers, or employees. Stock price and working capital are king, and this guides most short and long term decisions in the company. Expect the quality of your benefits to decline every year, either in monetary value or flexibility. For example, raises were awarded, frozen, and then taken away in 2020. During benefits enrollment, they advertised no increase in premiums...for those who did not see a salary increase. For those who did, they were tagged with a 40% increase. Honeywell had recently increased the company match from 6% or 7%, but revised it to providing in a lump sum at the end of the year, offsetting any annual compounding they would have received.

review_title: Honeywell Voice Solutions, Stay away at all costs!
pros: *The front line workers and managers who built the product and business before Honeywell acquired still working there. There are still a few left, but unfortunately Honeywell has shown that within the last year they will remove positions without fully preparing for who and how the work will be handled.
cons:
*Very little to zero career opportunities
*Exceeding yearly goals and having merit increases removed
*More than 1 furlough a year
*Senior management focused on customer only, with little to no concern for employee development
*Worst communication ever witnessed within a business, Voice solutions was a small group within Intelligrated and items such as RIFs, furloughs, merit increase removal would be passed down well after the fact leaving managers zero time to prep to deliver news to employees
*Dishonest business tactics
*People with over 10 + years experience given 1 days notice that Honeywell no longer needs them. 
*No support for next generation product development
*Moving of Voice office building into downtown area because poor business decision made by Honeywell Robotics group. Not taking into considerations the double of commute time for most of their employees. Parking wasn't even thought about until after the fact now employees have to walk two blocks to work in the winter months in Pittsburgh.

review_title: Interesting, high-tech design work.  VERY poorly managed company.
pros: Extremely high-tech products and design opportunities at Mpls location. Still a few extremely bright, late-career engineers left to potentially provide learning/mentoring opportunities. (though this has dwindled significantly during covid layoffs and cuts to higher salaried employees)...
cons:
Poorly managed company from the top down. Job role quickly outpaces career progression for early career engeers, as promotions are almost nonexistent. Salary increases, upon promotion are dismal, at best.
Quarterly earnings numbers are companies' #1 concern. Employees come last (despite the constant internal self-promoting 'propaganda'). This can be summed up by a comedic example: Prices for employee "discounts" or accommodations on general consumer products is always significantly more expensive than prices found in local retailers...
Months after annual salary increases within Aerospace were approved (following a stellar & record year in earnings + revenue where many engineers and other salaried employees put in significant unpaid overtime) - they were all were cut to 0% a couple weeks before they were to take effect... Rational was "covid", despite PPE business unit taking in money hand over fist, alongside $15B in free govt handouts (which doesn't require repayment - similar to those received by airlines during 2020). The kicker? Executives & upper management made sure to pay themselves out their tens of millions in annual insentive/performance bonuses, less than a week before rolling back everyone else's salary increases to a flat zero for the previous record-breaking year...
Though not immediately apparent, HON hires PR firms to combat negative reviews online. I'd advise prospective employees to peruse through the endless stream of posts over the last few years on TheLayoff dot com...
Loosing market lead & competitiveness for many Mpls products at an alarming rate...

review_title: Top class multi industrial powerhouse with challenging work and great place to learn and develop
pros: Good commit to technology, IOT and furthering existing technologies in plants, buildings, aerospace and materials. Challenging work. Good work is rewarded and careers are accelerated. Goals are ambitious and broad. Real asset in sales and channels of distribution: multi channel powerhouse. Executives and key roles are strong in talent and great place to learn and develop. Leadership and "edgy" improvement principles engrained by Dave Cote are there and alive and vibrant.
cons: Challenge to balance long term and short term results = the pressure to perform short term sometimes overwhelms seed-planting emphasis and capacity.  The number of near term/ urgent improvement initiatives is vast and over powering. The commitment to operational excellence through Honeywell Operating System (HOS) has lost some focus as company has gone headlong into IOT, which is right direction. Needs a recommit to HOS to go along with new strategy. Sometimes matrix mgmt execution is more complex and gets in way of speedy execution. Balance of leadership has swung from empowerment with controls and deep dives to telling how it should be done.

job_title: Senior Inside Sales Supervisor in Houston, TX
pros: The only pro was the facility was nice.
cons: I have never experienced such blatant racism at a company in my life. From the beginning I was lied to about why the salary of my white subordinate male employee was greater than my own. Then I know this may sound cliche but I literally had to deal with a woman name Karen on a daily basis speaking to me in a degrading and disrespectful manner! I was lied to about the commission structure and how it would be based on G&O my first quarter there then all of a sudden they changed it to another metric to ensure I didn’t receive a payout (mind you I took a salary pay cut when I accepted this position because I was sold on the high commission structure) after only being employed for 5 months and in the middle of the current state of America with racism and the light now being shined on it I had the courage to look elsewhere. I am so happy I did because I am now at a company they truly cares about inclusion and diversity and am being compensated not based on the color of my skin or my gender but because it’s what I deserve professionally! Oh, I also went thru 3 different managers in the short time I was there, none of them took the time to fight for me or even get to know me, clearly because I am a black female. If you are black and female stay away from this company they do not respect or celebrate us there.

job_title: Chemical Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: I specifically worked at Honeywell UOP, based in Des Plaines, IL as part of their Career Development Program. Your coworkers are amazing, and there's knowledgable mentors available to help in many matters. The salary is great as well! The opportunities available to me at the company were definitely promising. It's just too bad the company was greatly affected by the pandemic.
cons: I specifically worked at Honeywell UOP, based in Des Plaines, IL as part of their Career Development Program. Management and business groups were constantly changing. I never felt secure in my place at the company. They were quite unforgiving in their layoffs, choosing new hires, employees of over 10+ years, and college hires that had yet to even start (they rescinded their job offers after multiple delays). Main headquarters in Des Plaines was outdated and felt like I traveled back in a time machine to the 80's or 90's. It all felt very corporate in the sense that your manager really didn't care about you, and as well, your manager had very little control over the corporate mandates.

job_title: Sourcing Program Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Honeywell has good base pay

pros:
Coworkers were amazing when i started but they’re all gone now.
Pay used to be average now it’s below competitors.
cons:
The coworkers were great when I first started, then came layoffs, short staffing, and overworked employees: those that survive the layoffs are left to take over the workload of their former coworkers, for LESS money than 2019 as they cancelled all raises, and they furloughed everyone TWICE in 2020. They also had temporary layoffs, and they called back favourites first instead of going by seniority. Everything is about cost cutting, all forms of employee engagement are gone (can’t even get a free hat, and don’t even mention the words “Christmas party”), we’re expected to do Honeywell mandatory trainings but not charge overtime for it if you’ve already worked your hours. 

The management used to be amazing back in the day, but they too were laid off in the past few years and their previous roles merged with others in sherwood park who are completely disconnected from our local office. You’re scene as a number, it’s revenue or nothing, no one cares to send a happy birthday, or congratulations on 5 years of service, or ask about how you’re doing as a person. They dont care about the mental health of their employees.

Benefits? Dont even get me started on benefits. Every year our portion of the benefits goes up, while Honeywells portion goes down; even though they send out all these emails about how much profits are coming in. Pensions are non existent unless you were around before they cut them out, so all the newcomers dont get any which i didn’t even think was possible, but again cost cutting for the worker so the board and shareholder get more profits in their pockets.

Cant even find any office staff to help; its all offshored. 
IT - offshore (There’s one guy left in IT and even his job is not secure.)
PAYROLL- offshore
BENEFITS-offshore
 There used to be a ton of people willing to help if you needed something; now those couple people left have a common response “not my job” when asking for anything.

review_title: Bullied, Humiliated, Unsupported - Scapegoat for senior management screw-ups and bad company  decisions
pros: I experienced no pros at all
cons: Everything, my entire short experience was horrific, I left after 3 months. 2 weeks into the job my line manager was sacked, I was then given another line who hadn't worked in my product area. The business made awful business decisions which had catastrophic consequences on customers (had they known the truth, so many cover ups and untruths) It got so bad an NDA was put in front of me... I never signed it. This particular honeywell company had been acquired many years ago but that small narrow minded culture was alive and well amongst staff, even HR. It was a truly awful experience and I am only sorry I did not go to the media about what was going on within the business.... Loyal customers of years treated appallingly and staff being blamed for decisions made higher up the chain. Stay away from this organisation. I was honest and frank and told how it was and what I was seeing and experiencing, it didnt go down well that I was holding people accountable for their lack or no decision making at all, no plans in place, no systems and processes. I was 'marked down' because of it and when I was honest and told them I was unsupported and essentially being bullied, instead of having a duty of care to me, i was told off about the language I used. I wrote my resignation letter from immediate effect, gathered my things and walked out of this vile toxic company

pros: The people. In my over 20 years working for Honeywell, the one constant was working with good people.
cons:
Constant change in upper levels have led to a disconnect with their employees as well as a pretty steep drop in morale. There is very little communication between the upper management and lower levels.
They pay is competitive for new hires, but moving up within the company is limiting, with caps on how much of an increase can actually be made, even if the change in skill levels is drastic. Multiple people left just to come back at a higher rate of pay because of this limit. 
The inability to hire locally puts an added strain on managers and supervisors since it forces them to work 14 to 18 hour days to manage people in various time zones (My average day was 14 hours). Many managers have to take on the work of the employees they are trying to replace to meet deadlines, so this increases the stress. Very little Work-Life balance.
There are no bonuses for lower level management or general employees other than a Bravo, which are giving sparingly, and the compensation is low, even when the performance reviews are high, leading to a disgruntled workforce. 
Change to process without any consideration for the impact on work flow or adherence to standards needed to meet certain certifications causes extreme stress to the people who have to maintain those certifications, especially QA.
The strive for quality was overwhelmed by the need to meet numbers. What was once an industry of Safety and Quality because a battle of meeting numbers with no focus on making sure the product met the need and standards the customer came to expect with the Honeywell name.

review_title: Few Incentives to Stay, Lots of Reasons to Leave
job_title: Test Engineer II in Mason, OH
pros:
- The initial pay for most positions seems to be good. The increases afterwards are severely lacking, though.

- The benefits seem adequate to me.

- The hardware provided to employees is stellar in most cases, unless you receive a re-imaged laptop from another employee instead of a normal upgrade laptop.

- "Unlimited" vacation and reasonable sick time allowances.
cons:
- No Work From Home Policy
 Absolutely archaic way of looking at the work from home situation. Took corporate FOREVER to finally allow work from home during the pandemic compared to other businesses of similar caliber and size. The official plan is to have employees come back to the office 3 days a week starting July 6th, 2021, and then full-time back in the office sometime in the fall, September/October time-frame. With no planned exemptions or flexibility involved. The WFH policy up until this point is essentially "you can't" unless you're legally required to be allowed to. They claim that working in the office is better for collaboration and teamwork and innovation, but as an employee both before and after being purchased by Honeywell, I can tell you there is almost NO collaboration or innovation going on, nor is it actually incentivized. They just like the buzzwords.

- No Upward Mobility
 You would think a company like this would be incredibly interested in keeping the younger generation around and attracting young, new talent and retaining them to replace the "old guard" when they move on or retire, but they don't remotely care and it's obnoxiously evident. They drag out promotions for nearly a year or more, if you even get one at all. They get incredibly stingy with the raises when they actually do give them. They don't seem interested in giving you a career path, just expect you to be happy you're where you are and to stay there.

- 401K Paid Out Once Per Year
 They only pay 401k match once a year in January, meaning you lose out on potential dividends. interest gains, and general gains over the course of the year that they could have been matching monthly. This also means if you leave at any point other than right after you receive your match, you miss out on potentially 11 months worth of 401k match funds.

- Furloughs and Cut Cost-of-Living Raises are the Norm
 It's very typical to be furloughed, even as an engineer, for anywhere from 1 week to 1 full month every year. That's a lot of time that you can't really plan for to go without a paycheck, and there's no telling when they decide the financials need to look better, so everyone should take one for the team. They also frequently find excuses to not offer the yearly cost-of-living wage increases; Usually it's that the financial performance hasn't been great, despite having just shown slides that seemed an awful lot like the company was doing pretty good.

- Inefficient, Silo'd Engineering & Lack of Training
 Almost all engineering teams work in silos all the time and team collaboration is just handled at the end when it has to be done, instead of integrating things throughout the course of development. There is also little to no training. If you ever do go through training, it's usually way to late to have ever been useful, but the training itself isn't usually actually helpful in the first place so it's really wouldn't matter.

- Heavy Focus on Short-Term Stockholder Gains
 Most of the town-halls and other company-wide meetings usually cover financials from a high-level perspective talking about how great we are usually doing, and quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year financial improvements. As well as how great this would be for the stockholders. This wouldn't be such an issue if it weren't for the people that make the business profitable (the sales teams and the engineering teams) weren't treated as a disposable meat grinder. There is no conversation had about employee retention or what could be helpful to keep employees, giving the impression to back up the evidence, that they couldn't care less whether you stay or go.

 - Lots of Broken Promises
 They frequently like to have "surveys" that a mysteriously large portion of the company report never receiving and use these surveys to justify the state of things, while making "promises" and "plans" on how to "improve" things that NEVER actually come to fruition in any way more than an abstract "we should be doing this" conversation in a town-hall.

- Hemorrhaging Employees
 Employee retention seems to be the last concern to upper-management. I've heard losses of engineering employees described as "un-regrettable losses". That speaks for itself.

job_title: Lead Enterprise Architect in Tempe, AZ
pros: The compensation aligned with what I was expecting and the benefits were decent given the relationships and reputation Honeywell has with outside parties.
cons:
There are not enough words in this box to fully articulate the cons with this organization. 

I was horribly misled about the job position, description, and responsibilities. I relocated to Tempe, AZ for the position. Three weeks into the job I went on a mandatory furlough. Not exactly comforting considering I relocated over 1,000 miles for the position, selling my home, and living in a new area. Feedback from peers and others in the organization articulated this was "the norm" for the organization. 

I was told the position was identifying and collaborating with other business units to provide recommendations with the goal to increase the cybersecurity maturity and hygiene of networks throughout the enterprise. I arrive at the position and am ready to dive right in. "Another team manages that" or "another team is responsible for that" became frequent statements when asking questions. You have a question on a firewall? Go talk to this team. You have a question on how the network is configured? Go talk to that team. Any attempts to build a relationship, collaborate, request access (even view only) to learn the lay of the land and how things are configured ended up in black holes. Neither of those teams are forthcoming with information even though it was your assigned responsibility. I don't know whether it was the fear of job security or just internal politics, but it was nearly impossible to get anything done. If you had an idea or a suggestion, you had to have a meeting about it. Not only did you have to have a meeting about it, but you had to have a meeting to talk about needing to have a meeting for it. 8 hours in a 10 hour workday was spent in non-productive meetings, but they were mandatory and you couldn't get out of them. 

The internal politics are the worst that I have ever seen. 

My direct manager was great. He was always willing and able to try to clear any roadblocks I had, but even he couldn't bulldoze through the existing political roadblocks or immaturity of some of the other team and their leads.

I should have heeded HR's warning about the politics during onboarding more instead of just shrugging it off that every company has political issues.

job_title: Chemical Engineer I in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: Best company to work at for a fresher.
cons: Workload is too much sometimes

pros: There are a lot of smart, talented people you will work with. However, the running joke is "it's the place where smart people go to feel bad about themselves." If you are willing to relocate, you can move up in the company.
cons:
Too many to list, but here are the main cons:
-Work/life balance: This is one of the biggest concerns across the company. We are a global organization so it's common to have early morning (6:00 am) and evening meetings (after 7:00 pm) and also working weekends and during "vacations". There is no consideration for personal commitments outside of work. You don't ever really get to take a vacation because you are still expected to check emails, attend meetings, etc.
-Workloads: Due to significant layoffs across the company, most people are doing the job of 2 and 3 people. During the pandemic, there were times where the finance teams were pulling all nighters and working until midnight most days of the weeks. We had employees quitting after a couple months due to the workloads.
-Diversity: Within the past year, they jumped on the diversity bandwagon but is disingenuous. I've observed them promote women or persons of color and shortly thereafter fire them and replace with a white male.
-Compensation/Benefits: Benefits are subpar, 0% vesting on 401k until 3 years. In order to get health benefits you have to do a medical screening. Compensation is terrible. 2020 was a tough year for most companies but Honeywell was still meeting their financial commitments to the street yet not giving salary increases and little to no bonus. Also, to increase savings for the year, they would layoff employees a few weeks prior to bonus payouts and merit increases.
-Culture: It's a punishment-based culture. The CEO sent an email to his leaders that ended-up making it's way throughout the org, basically encouraging his leaders to rule with an iron-fist, and by creating an environment of fear and more "stick" and less "carrot" will make you a more successful leader. They live for the month and quarter which means they will push and drive at all cost to meet their numbers to the street. This is great from a shareholder perspective, but unbearable at times from an employee perspective.

review_title: Toxic culture flowed down from executive level
pros: Excellent place to gain experience, especially with lean manufacturing certifications. Great safety culture at the factory level but the executive level is becoming less and less supportive of safety.

They company is driven by ensuring the stock price is up which means they often take extreme cost-cutting measures for the inorganic growth. Many times this comes at the expense of the employees and even the customers. The executive level, especially in Aerospace, is completely toxic, they continually belittle people in meetings and on conference calls.

review_title: Great to learn, Challenge to life
pros:
1) You will work with some amazing people in this company!

The senior HR leadership team is made up of an ambitious, challenging and intelligent group of people who have a strong business sense and know how to ask the right questions, streamline processes for efficiency and take responsibility to get a job done.

2) Salary is higher than average

Honeywell tends to pay above market rate due to the culture of high performance high reward that is promoted within

3) The culture

The culture within Honeywell is not for everyone, but if you are looking for a challenge, interested in continuous development and willing and able to go the extra mile to perform then it may be a good fit for you. There is a lot to learn here and it can definitely stretch your comfort zone, which can be a good or bad thing
cons:
1) Work Life Balance

As with anything there are always two sides to a coin. Whilst Honeywell is an amazing place to work, it can be challenging to get your work-life balance right if you are looking to perform well. Nobody will actively encourage you to create that balance, so it is up to you to set your boundaries - so do not expect any kind of empathy or molly-coddling from this company. You’re there to work and be productive - that’s it

2) Flexibility

They removed the work from home policy before the pandemic on a global scale, meaning that working from home was not allowed unless you had a special exemption in place. This may have changed, but previously made it challenging to work flexibly within the company policy structure

3) Progression Opportunities

Although Honeywell is a huge company, they are also working towards streamlining their sites. As such, if you do want to move around you may find it challenging to find positions outside specific “hubs”. They have also been actively working at flattening the organisation to 6 layers from the bottom to CEO level and reducing the number of executives and Band 4 positions that they have, thus reducing the number of progression opportunities available once you reach a certain level

job_title: Senior Global Commodity Manager in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great pay and mediocre benefits.
cons:
They bill themselves as a technology company but they're really make profit by buying other companies. This creates many disconnected systems and non-robust processes which sets up the average employee for failure. You can be successful at Honeywell, but you're going to have to put in double the hours for the same result that you would have gotten at a more reputable company.

They're also more interested in manipulating their stock price via supply chain tricks than they are with driving stock prices up by delivering sold products to their customers. It's only a matter of time before all the work they get will be legacy work and then they're circling the drain. Stock price is inflated.

review_title: Think twice before you come here...
pros: The Honeywell brand is well recognized but I can only speak about HBT. If you are experienced in the Automation/Controls or Fire/Security industry, this may be a good place for you. Pay is good.
cons: Annual rises are minimally based on performance. As a Manager you define who get's what but it gets tweaked elsewhere, who knows why. You work/life balance will be almost non-existing requiring you to be available even when on vacation. Processes/Procedures/Standards are a joke. If you come from a different industry, prepare mentally as you will be taught to swim by pushing you into the deepest part of the pool without any flotation device (learn or die). Timely support will be minimal, if at all.

job_title: Design Engineer III in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
1.	Brand- Good (UOP has very good reputation, but after Honeywell overtaken UOP- Brand name has started degrading. But still it is good)
2.	Documentation- Good (Well documented knowledge) 
3.	Compensation- Moderate (with respective to the workload, feel compensation is too low)
4.	Office timing- Feasible (since company is target based company; so office timing is not so important)
5.	Travel- Moderate (Frequent US or UK travel required but limited duration one or two weeks)
cons:
1.	Work load- High (comparatively high work load at NAO, Hydrotreating groups) 
2.	Training- Poor (skill training, technology training- Nil, but Company provides one time intensive training to get hand off of the UOP design tools)
3.	Work environment- Poor (Exp. people and Management feel insure and created a poor working environment)
4.	Ethics- less (not Employee friendly, Poor HR policies, unusual firing at critical/ pandemic situations without proper reason, Salary deductions, etc)
5.	Job Security- less (US based company- hire and fire policy. Anything can happen at any time) 
6.	Growth- Slow (initially 5 years growth will be slow, since it is management judging time of your capabilities)
7.	Knowledge- less (Well documented knowledge, but it is hard to get time to go through it)
8.	Engineering Tools- Up to mark (Well designed UOP engineering tool- we get knowledge how to play with the tools but not the content)
9.	Technology exposure- Moderate (until Process coordinator (min. 5years) is zero, later exposure is good) 
10.	Politics- High (Ratio of Managers to working staff is more, regional feelings are high)

Final words- Honeywell UOP is good brand company with moderate compensation, less Job Security Company and required minimum 5 years in the UOP to gain/ start some exposure in the technologies.

pros:
- Two weeks vacation, but vacation time increases the longer you stay - up to four weeks vacation time.
- In addition to vacation time, there is personal time off (PTO)
- Health insurance
- Dental insurance
- 401K matching (conditional - see cons)
cons:
- Low pay
- They do not match your 401K on a monthly basis - they will deposit it at the beginning of the next year, so if you leave the company before mid-December, you get no 401K match for the year. None!
- No career ladder
- Global corporation that works to please its shareholders first
- They are good at spending millions to acquire other companies, but barely give employees a cost of living pay increase.

job_title: Project Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Honeywell UOP was a great place to work with an amazing culture however that has all changed by the upper management/ELT actions or lack of actions. Communication is a major issue within the organization. There use to be a culture of learning and building together to provide our customer with the best service and equipment. That mindset is gone, it all lip service now. We are not even given the tools to do our job (takes a director to approve a request to replace a broken headset) and lack of basic support structure (onboarding, IT, admins).
cons: This year has been difficult for all. We went from hiring multiple people to 3 RIF, 3 weeks of furloughs, no pay increases, and early retirement packages. There is no communication from upper management which creates uncertainty and anxiety within the project teams. Projects are forced to use purchase services to complete tasks which leads to quality issues and delays. Upper management/ELT seems completely unaware of how their actions or lack of actions are perceived by the lower ranks
